body:
could you please provide a self-contained example, i.e., one that does not use an external package?

The issue might be with `yfinance` not setting the `freq` parameter in the loaded data frame.

@fkiraly question: if the dataframe has dates that are not uniformally spaced, for example holidays as missing data, what can be done? It assumes that all rows have no null values in multivariate forecasting.
P.S. will draft an example that does something similar based on [This ZIP file](https://github.com/CNuge/kaggle-code/tree/master/stock_data) and [This Table](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/camnugent/sandp500) and provide an example.

@BrandonKMLee, most forecasters assume equally spaced data. You can bin the data using `pandas.cut` or the `PandasTransformAdapter` in the pipeline.

It would be much preferred if your example did not require loading and downloading of any extrinsic data, kindly provide a self-contained example.

Observe the following table, where it is clearly a daily info dataset, however as you can see, it missed holidays and weekend. What can be done to make this data usable to sktime, as often it is the case that the data is constrained by use cases, and that binning within the week is considered unsuitable (e.g. doing daily forecast)? Also, which forecasters can handle non purely spaced data (e.g. prophet)?
[spx.csv](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/files/9740625/spx.csv)

One could argue your example is "B" frequency not "D" 

https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/timeseries.html#dateoffset-objects
Also I recommend using `df.resample(freq).bfill()` or your interpolation method of choice...unless you are 100% certain the accuracy of your input data's index is pristine (it probably isn't).

@topher-lo thanks for the help, in that case how can one rewrite the whole DataFrame conversion line since I am not sure about the `freq` in `df.resample(freq).bfill()`. Hopefully the "facts on the ground" does not conflict with the software's definition of business days.
Also this is surprising https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/timeseries.html#offset-aliases

issue.title: Lack of Freq String for Daily Prices

repository.name: yfinance
repository.description: Download market data from Yahoo! Finance's API

issue.body:
From https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3543#issuecomment-1272305001
It seems that when acquiring the daily data, the `freq` string is not set to `'B'` or "business days", so some of the code may not work normally.

body:
If you have a DataFrame with multiindex (date, symbol), you can use this simple trick:
```python
df.unstack("symbol").resample("freq").bfill().stack("symbol")
```

Also you can specify custom business days: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/timeseries.html#custom-business-days

> Also, which forecasters can handle non purely spaced data (e.g. prophet)? [spx.csv](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/files/9740625/spx.csv)

Prophet interpolates NaNs under the hood. I would be weary of passing in finance data (sampled at "D" with weekend and public holiday NaNs) directly into prophet because the way it interpolates these gaps might not be causally sound. You can interpolate the data yourself as part of a sktime pipeline.

Also @fkiraly I think this issue should be moved to discussions.

Also before moving this to discussions (IDK how to move this), for the sake of ease of use (since `resample` and `inferred_freq` fails to check the data in `yfinance` API), I made this and hopefully it can be included in pandas or sktime?
```Python
from numpy import arange, mean, abs, array
from pandas.core.series import Series
def findSampleFreq(ts:Series, n:int=None):
# cleaned from https://stackoverflow.com/a/61479277
# a very coarse estimator in case the following links fail at checking which type it is
# https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DatetimeIndex.inferred_freq.html
# https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.resample.html

  t_diffs = []
  if n == None: n = ts.shape[0]-1
  # TODO: check if n is smaller than ts.shape[0]-1
  for i in arange(n):
      td = ts.iloc[i+1]-ts.iloc[i]
      t_diffs.append(td)

  avg_diff = mean(t_diffs)

  # counting as SI day rather than mean solar day
  diff_ns = avg_diff.value 
  diff_us = diff_ns / 1000
  diff_ms = diff_us / 1000
  diff_sec = diff_ms / 1000    
  diff_min = diff_sec / 60
  diff_hour = diff_min / 60
  diff_biz = (diff_hour / 24) / (7 / 5) # assert no holidays
  diff_day = diff_hour / 24
  diff_wk = diff_day / 7
  # counting Julian leap years
  diff_semi = diff_day / 15.21875 # assert 0.5 month instead of 2 weeks
  diff_month = diff_day / 30.4375 
  diff_qtr = diff_day / 91.3125
  diff_yr = diff_day / 365.25

  #the unit having minimum absolute difference with 1
  # is the sampling freq
  diffs = list(abs(1 - array([diff_ns, diff_us, diff_ms,
          diff_sec, diff_min, diff_hour,
          diff_biz, diff_day, diff_wk,
          diff_semi, diff_month, diff_qtr, 
          diff_yr])))

  aliases = ['N', 'U', 'L', 'S', 'T', 'H', 
             'B', 'D', 'W', 'SMS', 'MS', 'QS', 'AS']
  # https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/timeseries.html#dateoffset-objects
  id = diffs.index(min(diffs))
  return aliases[id]
```

Idea: regularizing data into formats that does not require timezones (if models do not need it), or defaults to a certain timezone if it does. also if interval is small, regularize through proxy binning to the suitable second/minute/hour.
